awd_titl_txt: DIMENSIONS: Collaborative Research: The Making of Biodiversity Across the Yeast Subphylum
awd_abstract_narration:
The yeasts are model organisms for understanding and integrating the genetic and ecological factors that drive species diversification and generate biodiversity. Yeasts show remarkably different types of metabolism, allowing them to successfully inhabit every continent and every major aquatic and terrestrial habitat, however little is known about the distribution of these traits among the diversity of yeast species. By creating and analyzing the first comprehensive genomic dataset and catalog of metabolic diversity for a high-level taxonomic rank (subphylum), this project will provide insight into how key changes in metabolism shape eukaryotic microbial ecology and diversity. Inclusive large-scale analysis of the genome data will be fostered by creating an interactive web-based interface for researchers, clinicians, teachers, and students to explore the subphylum as a model for understanding the making of biodiversity. These data will be of potential value for practitioners using yeast to improve industrial and medical processes. 

The goals of this project are to determine the metabolic and ecological diversity of the Saccharomycotina subphylum at the genetic and phenotypic (e.g. metabolism, morphology) levels, and then to infer the tempo and mode of change across its history. To determine the genetic basis of metabolic diversity, the project will generate functionally annotated genome sequences for all ~1,000 known species and compare genome content with ecological and metabolic data from the entire subphylum. The project will accurately reconstruct the phylogenetic relationships of all known species and will use these relationships to develop a stable taxonomy of medically and biotechnologically important yeasts. The project will provide new insights into the manner in which biodiversity arises and the key changes that drive and shape it by tracing the history of yeast metabolism, ecology, and pathogenicity.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Diverse yeasts have evolved over hundreds of millions of years to manage carbon and energy differently from one another. The gene networks governing these decisions and capabilities determine their diverse ecologies, lifestyles, metabolisms, and potential applications. Yeasts provide an unmatched experimental system to answer several questions: A) How are metabolic functions genetically encoded? B) How did they evolve? C) How can they be manipulated for sustainable human benefit? D) What general principles do they reveal about life? Budding yeasts of the subphylum Saccharomycotina include the model yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and the opportunistic pathogen Candida albicans. More than 1000 species are known, and they are as diverse genetically as the entire plant or animal kingdom. They have evolved to fill metabolically diverse niches in every biome. Through the Y1000+ Project (y1000plus.org), the research team sequenced and analyzed the genomes of nearly every known species of budding yeast to understand how their genomes encode diverse phenotypes, how they have evolved, and how they can be used to benefit humanity. Highlights include phylogenetic reconstruction of a strong trend of gene and trait loss during evolution; discovery of the first budding yeast secondary metabolite gene cluster; discovery of a 7-gene operon horizontally transferred from bacteria into a group of yeasts; discovery of multiple trait syndromes or trait-trait correlations; discovery of a novel nuclear genetic code; discovery of multiple reinventions of mating-type switching, discovery of a group of yeasts that lost and regained alcoholic fermentation; discovery of a group of yeasts that lost several key DNA repair, cell cycle, and metabolic pathways; multiple investigations into the molecular mechanisms of evolution using the model GALactose utilization pathway; and draft genotype-phenotype map of budding yeast metabolism. A comprehensive and integrative manuscript summarizing the cumulative results of the project has been drafted and will be submitted soon.

 

Broader Impacts: As part of the Yeast Exploration and Analysis Science Team, dozens of undergraduate researchers isolated thousands of new yeast strains while learning genetics, microbiology, ecology, and bioinformatics. Wild YEAST Program trainees have mostly been women, and many have been drawn from underrepresented minority backgrounds. Our most recent survey paper analyzed the largest collection of yeasts isolated from a common set of enrichment protocols to reveal several ecological associations between yeasts and substrates and to suggest several ways to maximize the recovery of yeast diversity. Notable and surprising discoveries include the isolation of dozens of strains of opportunistic pathogens from natural settings, including Candida albicans and Candida glabrata. Based on Wild YEAST Program discoveries, the team is currently using genome sequences and rich phenotypic data to formally describe and name dozens of new species in the taxonomic literature using new “taxogenomic” approaches.

At UW-Madison, the Principal Investigator (PI) has been particularly active in service to the J. F. Crow Institute for the Study of Evolution where they served as the Director since 2019, as well as on its governing body and 3 standing committees. Notable accomplishments during my tenure as Director include creating and serving on a standing Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Committee; maintaining a vibrant seminar series with an average attendance of ~50; expanding the Early Career Scientists Symposium to focus on recruiting diverse extramural speakers; reorganizing the course Genetics/Biology 522: Communicating Evolutionary Biology; and successfully shifting institute operations to being fully virtual and now hybrid during the pandemic.

During this project, the PI also served the broader genetics, microbiology, and evolutionary biology communities at the national and international levels. The PI regularly serves on grants panels, review grants, and review manuscripts for the top journals and major funders in the field. The PI is on the Editorial Boards of mBio, Trends in Genetics, Yeast, and Frontiers in Fungal Biology, and they served as a guest editor for PNAS,eLife, mBio, and PLoS Genetics. The lab maintains a large strain collection for the community and have shared >3,250 strains and plasmids with >130 labs in >25 countries. The PI has served as an external reviewer for 3 cases for promotion to associate professor with tenure and for fellowship in the Royal Society of Canada. The PI served on the Cross-Community Workshop Committee of The Allied Genetics Conference of 2020 (Genetics Society of America) and as a mentor and discussion leader at the 2019 Molecular Mechanisms of Evolution Gordon Research Conference. The PI represents the USA on the International Commission on Yeasts, served on the International Scientific Committee for its 2018 meeting, and served on the Organizing Committee for its 2022 meeting.
